docs.lead_paragraph: Several groups of Denver-area doctors who specialize in obstetrics and gynecology have agreed to settle accusations that they fixed fees, causing increased costs for their services, the Federal Trade Commission said today. The F.T.C. accused eight doctor groups with a total of more than 80 doctors and their agent, Todd Welter, a consultant, of entering arrangements and boycotts to fix prices and other terms.

headline.main: Denver Doctor Groups Settle Case on Fees

docs.abstract: Federal Trade Commission says several groups of Denver-area doctors who specialize in obstetrics and gynecology agree to settle accusations that they fixed fees, causing increased costs for their services; FTC accused eight doctor groups with total of more than 80 doctors and their agent Todd Welter, consultant, of entering arrangements and boycotts to fix prices and other terms; also persuaded physicians to eliminate ties to independent practice associations and practice management groups; settlement makes sure those engaged in practices will not do so in future, bars Welter for three years from negotiating with any payer on behalf of doctor groups or advising current or former members of groups on any agreements and forces groups to terminate any contracts at request of payer 'to eliminate effects of respondents' anticompetitive actions; eight physician groups listed (M)
docs.snippet: Several groups of Denver-area doctors who specialize in obstetrics and gynecology have agreed to settle accusations that they fixed fees, causing increased costs for their services, the Federal Trade Commission said today.    The F.T.C. accused eight...

docs.lead_paragraph: MANY beachgoers make do with basic gear: a swimsuit, a towel, a summer novel. But a spate of new patent applications suggests that inventors think the beach experience can be improved, although it will remain for the Office of Patents and Trademarks to determine whether any of these ideas deserve patent protection. One of the hopefuls is Shannon Nation, who has invented a beach chair for pregnant women, providing a big hole in the middle so that an expectant mother can lie prone.

headline.main: Patents; A pool in the ocean. A tanning oil mister. Are those pasties? Inventing by the sea.

docs.abstract: New beach-related patents include those covering beach chair for pregnant women, with big hole in middle so that expectant mother can lie prone while reading (drawing), ocean-going swimming pool, shower-like cabinet in which tanning lotions can be evenly sprayed on body, plastic sun shields for the ears and strapless swimsuit top that is held on breasts by means of waterproof adhesive and resembles pasties worn by strip-tease artists (M)
docs.snippet: MANY beachgoers make do with basic gear: a swimsuit, a towel, a summer novel. But a spate of new patent applications suggests that inventors think the beach experience can be improved, although it will remain for the Office of Patents and Trademarks...

docs.lead_paragraph: A day after a pregnant woman was struck on a Brooklyn street at midday, she and her infant, who was delivered later, remained in separate hospitals, the woman in critical condition and the baby in serious condition, the authorities said. The crash happened at 2:50 p.m. Saturday in Park Slope, the police said, as the victim, Marcy Gordon, who was eight months pregnant, placed a child into a safety seat in her car, which was parked on 12th Street.

headline.main: Infant and Mother Badly Hurt After Being Struck by Car

docs.abstract: Marcy Gordon remains in critical condition one day after being hit by car driven by Grace Rignola in Park Slope, Brooklyn; Gordon, who was eight months pregnant, delivers baby by emergency Caesarean section; Rignola is charged with drunken driving and leaving scene of accident (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The jovial voice on the other end of the phone was that of Robert Keahey, the district attorney for the First Judicial Circuit of Alabama, which includes the tiny town of Butler in Choctaw County. Mr. Keahey is the prosecutor who brought capital murder charges against three retarded individuals for the murder of an infant, despite the fact that he could not show that the infant had ever existed, much less been killed.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column examines convictions of three indigent, black Alabama residents--Victoria Banks, husband Medell Banks and sister Dianne Tucker--for murder of infant, even though prosecutor, Robert Keahy, was unable to provide any evidence that infant ever existed (M)
docs.snippet: The jovial voice on the other end of the phone was that of Robert Keahey, the district attorney for the First Judicial Circuit of Alabama, which includes the tiny town of Butler in Choctaw County.    Mr. Keahey is the prosecutor who brought capital...

docs.lead_paragraph: During my early childhood I lived in four or five different homeless shelters in New York City. It's a good thing my mother found employment when she did; otherwise I, too, might have been like one of the homeless children in the city today, left without even a shelter to live in because of overcrowding. Last week some of these children were sent to an unused jail in the Bronx -- and then removed when lead paint was found there -- because the city could find nowhere else for them to live. From a house to a shelter to a former jail -- not the most desirable pathway to take in life. I only had to deal with having to write down an address in school that was never going to be my own, living in a ''house'' where I had an extended family of 100 strangers, being cramped in a room as small as a bathroom with three other families besides my own, with no sense of privacy -- ever. Some homeless children in New York can now add to their childhood memories the time they had no place else to live but a former jail.

headline.main: When Shelter Feels Like a Prison

docs.lead_paragraph: The central moral struggle of the 19th century concerned slavery, and that of the 20th pitted democracy against Nazism, Communism and other despotic isms. Our own pre-eminent moral challenge will be to ease the brutality that kills and maims girls and women across much of Africa and Asia. Alas, this summer President Bush is putting the U.S. on the wrong side of the battle lines.
docs.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column says health and welfare of women, particularly in Third World, is key issue of new century and Pres Bush is repeatedly putting United States on wrong side of battle lines by thwarting international efforts and cutting off aid; says that 500,00 women die each year in pregnancy or childbirth; that 100 million women and girls worldwide are 'missing' because they are denied food or medical care, or because they are aborted or killed at birth because they are female; and that between one and two million girls and women are trafficked into prostitution annually (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A conversation transcript in Science Times on Aug. 6 with Dr. Charles Lockwood, a leading researcher on premature babies, included an outdated reference to his affiliation. Since July, Dr. Lockwood has been chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at the Yale School of Medicine; he was previously chairman at New York University.
docs.abstract: Correction: conversation transcript in Aug 6 Science Times with Dr Charles Lockwood, leading researcher on premature babies, did not give his current affiliation with Yale School of Medicine
